page.title: 09MOORSHOLM: LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Entered in the Domesday Book of 1086 as Morehusum ({Houses on the {moor}). The character has changed very little since the 19th. century due to by-passing road links. The former Station Hotel is a reminder of the 1860-1900 ironstone mining boom in the area. It was built to cater for expected trade from the proposed Cleveland Extension Mineral Railway, known locally as Paddy Waddell's Railway. The name being derived from its contractor, John Waddell and his Irish engineer (Gallaher). The railway, with the intended ironstone mining along its route from Kilton to Glaisdale, could have brought about social and economic changes to Moorsholm. The work was never finished due to lack of public funding. Evidence of cuttings and embankments still remains.
